elements.content: Here we report the first utilization of the novel methane tetra-p-phenylphosphonic acid (MTPPA) ligand for the preparation of metal complexes with Cu­(II). The hydrothermal and solvothermal reactions of tetratopic MTPPA as a bridging ligand in conjunction with the square pyramidal {Cu­(terpy)}2+ and {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+, (where terpy = 2,2′:6′,2″-Terpyridine and pbterpy = 4′,4″″-(1,4-Phenylene)­bis­(2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine)) as prefixed corner building units have produced one-dimensional [{Cu­(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)]·(4.25H2O)­(H3O) (1) and two-dimensional [{Cu2(pbterpy)}­MTPPA-H4] (2), respectively. The structures were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and TGA.
elements.clean_text: Here we report the first utilization of the novel methane tetra-p-phenylphosphonic acid (MTPPA) ligand for the preparation of metal complexes with Cu(II). The hydrothermal and solvothermal reactions of tetratopic MTPPA as a bridging ligand in conjunction with the square pyramidal {Cu(terpy)}2+ and {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+, (where terpy = 2,2':6',2"-Terpyridine and pbterpy = 4',4""-(1,4-Phenylene)bis(2,2':6',2"-terpyridine)) as prefixed corner building units have produced one-dimensional [{Cu(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)]⋅(4.25H2O)(H3O) (1) and two-dimensional [{Cu2(pbterpy)}MTPPA-H4] (2), respectively. The structures were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and TGA.

elements.content:
A perspective view of the repeat unit in complex [{Cu2(pbterpy)}­MTPPA-H4], (MTPPA = methane tetra-p-phenylphosphonic acid).

Introduction

Carboxylate based MOFs have provided the porous platforms required for catalysis drug delivery and sorption. Due to the structural simplicity and rigidity of trigonal planar carboxylate groups, many well-established secondary building units have been identified to perform isoreticular expansions to engineer the MOF pore sites for the most optimum host guest relationships. Most of the aromatic carboxylates have been exploited as linker molecules in producing novel MOFs. Alternative bridging ligand types are needed to expand the current MOF research into different fields. Some of the alternative adhesive units for unconventional MOFs include organophosphonate and arsenate compounds. Organophosphonates have tetrahedral adhesive units with variable protonation states producing distinct coordination modes. While rich coordination possibilities of metal phosphonates result in extremely diverse structural chemistry producing a wide range of applications, at the same time structural diversity means more possibilities for potential SBUs and less predictable MOF structure.
elements.clean_text:
A perspective view of the repeat unit in complex [{Cu2(pbterpy)}MTPPA-H4], (MTPPA = methane tetra-p-phenylphosphonic acid).

Introduction

Carboxylate based MOFs have provided the porous platforms required for catalysis drug delivery and sorption. Due to the structural simplicity and rigidity of trigonal planar carboxylate groups, many well-established secondary building units have been identified to perform isoreticular expansions to engineer the MOF pore sites for the most optimum host guest relationships. Most of the aromatic carboxylates have been exploited as linker molecules in producing novel MOFs. Alternative bridging ligand types are needed to expand the current MOF research into different fields. Some of the alternative adhesive units for unconventional MOFs include organophosphonate and arsenate compounds. Organophosphonates have tetrahedral adhesive units with variable protonation states producing distinct coordination modes. While rich coordination possibilities of metal phosphonates result in extremely diverse structural chemistry producing a wide range of applications, at the same time structural diversity means more possibilities for potential SBUs and less predictable MOF structure.

elements.content: The predictability of the ultimate structure of organophosphonate based MOFs requires significant research efforts to produce a large library of metal-organophosphonate compounds to develop the design elements, corresponding SBUs, and reaction conditions to perform SBU based isoreticular expansions. There are only three reports that have shown SBU based isoreticular expansions of metal-organophosphonate compounds via changing the tether lengths of bridging ligands. All three reports have included H2O3PCH2-NR-CH2PO3H2 adhesive group where the central nitrogen atom fixes the location of metal coordination in between the two phosphonate groups. There have been no reports on isoreticular expansions of naked phosphonate units yet. The diverse coordination modes of metal-organophosphonate chemistry suggest that alternative methods should be considered in constructing metal-phosphonate MOFs using naked aromatic phosphonate bridging ligands.
elements.clean_text: The predictability of the ultimate structure of organophosphonate based MOFs requires significant research efforts to produce a large library of metal-organophosphonate compounds to develop the design elements, corresponding SBUs, and reaction conditions to perform SBU based isoreticular expansions. There are only three reports that have shown SBU based isoreticular expansions of metal-organophosphonate compounds via changing the tether lengths of bridging ligands. All three reports have included H2O3PCH2-NR-CH2PO3H2 adhesive group where the central nitrogen atom fixes the location of metal coordination in between the two phosphonate groups. There have been no reports on isoreticular expansions of naked phosphonate units yet. The diverse coordination modes of metal-organophosphonate chemistry suggest that alternative methods should be considered in constructing metal-phosphonate MOFs using naked aromatic phosphonate bridging ligands.

elements.content: One logical approach to increase the predictability in copper-organophosphonate systems is to engineer the coordination environment of metal centers by using chelating organoimine ligands to limit the number of phosphonate coordination over the copper coordination sphere. The chelating ligands including 2,2′:6′,2″-Terpyridine (terpy), 4′,4⁗-(1,4-Phenylene)­bis­(2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine) (pbterpy), or 2,2′-bipyridine (2,2′-bpy) regularly produce square pyramidal {Cu­(2,2′-bpy)}2+, {Cu­(terpy)}2+, and {Cu2(pbterpy)}2+ centers where Cu­(II) has two and three open sites for phosphonate coordination, respectively. This method has previously been shown to be influential in controlled formation of macrocyclic Cu­(II)-organophosphonate building blocks. Another report using a similar method has used a bridging 4,4′-bipyridine ligand to form isoreticular porous frameworks with the H2O3PCH2-NR-CH2PO3H2 type of organophosphonates. Hypothetically, increasing the number of blocked coordination sites over the copper coordination sphere would help the structural diversity be kept under control so that the predictability of the ultimate metal-organophosphonate compound is achieved.
elements.clean_text: One logical approach to increase the predictability in copper-organophosphonate systems is to engineer the coordination environment of metal centers by using chelating organoimine ligands to limit the number of phosphonate coordination over the copper coordination sphere. The chelating ligands including 2,2':6',2"-Terpyridine (terpy), 4',4⁗-(1,4-Phenylene)bis(2,2':6',2"-terpyridine) (pbterpy), or 2,2'-bipyridine (2,2'-bpy) regularly produce square pyramidal {Cu(2,2'-bpy)}2+, {Cu(terpy)}2+, and {Cu2(pbterpy)}2+ centers where Cu(II) has two and three open sites for phosphonate coordination, respectively. This method has previously been shown to be influential in controlled formation of macrocyclic Cu(II)-organophosphonate building blocks. Another report using a similar method has used a bridging 4,4'-bipyridine ligand to form isoreticular porous frameworks with the H2O3PCH2-NR-CH2PO3H2 type of organophosphonates. Hypothetically, increasing the number of blocked coordination sites over the copper coordination sphere would help the structural diversity be kept under control so that the predictability of the ultimate metal-organophosphonate compound is achieved.

elements.content: As seen in , the square pyramidal {Cu­(terpy)}2+ is a simple building unit that could coordinate to the organophosphonate ligands via its empty basal and apical coordination sites producing near 90° corners. In addition to limiting the number of potential phosphonate coordination, fixing the coordination angle to the metal center helps the predictability of the ultimate structure as well. To date, no systematic studies have been reported to test this hypothesis. We have recently reported the synthesis and crystal structures of tetrahedral methane tetra-p-phenylphosphonic acid (MTPPA), which is a remarkable ligand possessing a negative charge range between 0 and −8, thus providing a pH controlled platform for the oligomerization of Cu–P–O polyhedra in one, two, and three dimensions. Tetrahedral cavities of MTPPA are expected to form large void spaces when they are connected via the metal center to form two- and three-dimensional frameworks. Therefore, we have used the MTPPA ligand to coordinate over the two empty coordination sites of square pyramidal {Cu­(terpy)}2+ and {Cu2(pbterpy)}2+ building units to form our hybrid frameworks of one-dimensional [{Cu­(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)]·(4.25 H2O)­(H3O) and two-dimensional [{Cu2(pbterpy)}­(MTPPA-H4)], where 2,2′:6′,2″-Terpyridine = terpy, and 4′,4⁗-(1,4-Phenylene)­bis­(2,2′:6 ′,2″-terpyridine) = pbterpy. This study is the first report utilizing the novel MTPPA ligand to form the corresponding metal complexes with Cu­(II).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

As seen in , the square pyramidal {Cu(terpy)}2+ is a simple building unit that could coordinate to the organophosphonate ligands via its empty basal and apical coordination sites producing near 90° corners. In addition to limiting the number of potential phosphonate coordination, fixing the coordination angle to the metal center helps the predictability of the ultimate structure as well. To date, no systematic studies have been reported to test this hypothesis. We have recently reported the synthesis and crystal structures of tetrahedral methane tetra-p-phenylphosphonic acid (MTPPA), which is a remarkable ligand possessing a negative charge range between 0 and -8, thus providing a pH controlled platform for the oligomerization of Cu-P-O polyhedra in one, two, and three dimensions. Tetrahedral cavities of MTPPA are expected to form large void spaces when they are connected via the metal center to form two- and three-dimensional frameworks. Therefore, we have used the MTPPA ligand to coordinate over the two empty coordination sites of square pyramidal {Cu(terpy)}2+ and {Cu2(pbterpy)}2+ building units to form our hybrid frameworks of one-dimensional [{Cu(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)]⋅(4.25 H2O)(H3O) and two-dimensional [{Cu2(pbterpy)}(MTPPA-H4)], where 2,2':6',2"-Terpyridine = terpy, and 4',4⁗-(1,4-Phenylene)bis(2,2':6 ',2"-terpyridine) = pbterpy. This study is the first report utilizing the novel MTPPA ligand to form the corresponding metal complexes with Cu(II).

elements.content: {Cu­(terpy)}2+ building unit having two available sites for phosphonate coordination.
elements.clean_text: 1  {Cu(terpy)}2+ building unit having two available sites for phosphonate coordination.

elements.content: The first crystal structure of [{Cu­(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)]·(4.25 H2O)­(H3O) () consists of two similar one-dimensional zigzagged chains of [{Cu­(terpy)}­(MTPPA-H5)] and [{Cu­(terpy)}­(MTPPA-H6)] ( and Figure S1). The extra negative charge is counterbalanced by a hydronium ion and it has no significant contribution to the overall structure. The tau-descriptor (τ5) values for Cu1 and Cu1A atoms are 0.12 and 0.13, which indicate slightly significant distortion of the geometry (τ5 = 0 for an ideal square pyramid and τ5 = 1 for an ideal trigonal bipyramid). Both chains are formed by the coordination of single phosphonate oxygen arm originating from the two ends of the tetrahedral MTPPA-H6 and MTPPA-H5 ligands. MTPPA-H6 ligand has two full protonated phosphonate ends, while each of the two remaining single-protonated phosphonate end has overall −1 charge.
elements.clean_text: The first crystal structure of [{Cu(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)]⋅(4.25 H2O)(H3O) () consists of two similar one-dimensional zigzagged chains of [{Cu(terpy)}(MTPPA-H5)] and [{Cu(terpy)}(MTPPA-H6)] ( and Figure S1). The extra negative charge is counterbalanced by a hydronium ion and it has no significant contribution to the overall structure. The tau-descriptor (τ5) values for Cu1 and Cu1A atoms are 0.12 and 0.13, which indicate slightly significant distortion of the geometry (τ5 = 0 for an ideal square pyramid and τ5 = 1 for an ideal trigonal bipyramid). Both chains are formed by the coordination of single phosphonate oxygen arm originating from the two ends of the tetrahedral MTPPA-H6 and MTPPA-H5 ligands. MTPPA-H6 ligand has two full protonated phosphonate ends, while each of the two remaining single-protonated phosphonate end has overall -1 charge.

elements.content: Coordination environment of Cu­(II) atoms in two crystallographically independent 1D polymeric structures (a and b) in the asymmetric unit of complex 1. The hydrogen atoms, lattice water molecules, and hydronium ion are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) x, 3/2 – y, 1/2 + z; (ii) x, 3/2 − y, −1/2 + z; (iii) 1 − x, −1/2 + y, 3/2 − z; (iv) 1 − x, 1/2 + y, 3/2 − z.
elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination environment of Cu(II) atoms in two crystallographically independent 1D polymeric structures (a and b) in the asymmetric unit of complex 1. The hydrogen atoms, lattice water molecules, and hydronium ion are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) x, 3/2 - y, 1/2 + z; (ii) x, 3/2 - y, -1/2 + z; (iii) 1 - x, -1/2 + y, 3/2 - z; (iv) 1 - x, 1/2 + y, 3/2 - z.

elements.content: Perspective view of 1, showing a one-dimensional polymeric zigzag chain along the crystallographic b axis.
elements.clean_text: 3  Perspective view of 1, showing a one-dimensional polymeric zigzag chain along the crystallographic b axis.

elements.content: The analogous one-dimensional zigzagged [{Cu­(terpy)}/organophosphonate] pattern observed in 1 was previously seen in aliphatic organophosphonates as well. 1 was synthesized under hydrothermal reaction conditions. The adjustment of initial pH = 1 has increased the protonation level of the MTPPA ligand providing overall −2 negative charge limiting the growth in one dimension. The second two-dimensional compound [{Cu2(pbterpy)}­MTPPA-H4] was synthesized using the solvothermal methods in DMF ( and Figure S2). The TOPOS analysis of 2 indicates that the one-dimensional chain figure observed in 1 has retained its character. The one-dimensional chain structures observed in [{Cu­(terpy)}­MTPPA-H6] (1) were connected by the second copper originating from the {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+ unit to form the two-dimensional network of 2 (). The tau-descriptor (τ5) values for Cu1 and Cu2 atoms are 0.06 and 0.02, which indicate no significant distortion of the geometry when compared to complex 1. The tetrahedral MTPPA-H4 in 2 was observed as a result of the incorporation of the second Cu­(II) in {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+, which has produced the three distinct phosphonate ends. The first phosphonate end in 2 has a fully protonated R–PO3H2 unit, the second group is fully deprotonated R–PO3 –2 providing overall −2 negative charge, while the remaining two phosphonate adhesive units are half protonated R–PO3H–1 providing overall −2 negative charge. Half protonated phosphonate units of MTPPA-H4 linker follow a similar zigzagged one-dimensional chain pattern to that observed in 1. In conjunction with {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+ the fully deprotonated R–PO3 –2 unit of MTPPA-H4 is connecting the previously observed one-dimensional pattern in 1 to form the two-dimensional 2. The additional connectivity originated from the fully deprotonated phosphonate end in 2 has also produced the one-dimensional void chanel of {Cu2(MTPPA-H4)} via the {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+ end. The overall driving force behind the formation of the two-dimensional structure of 2 is the deprotonation of MTPPA-H6 ligand in 1 to accept the second Cu­(II) originating from the {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+, which is analogous to {Cu­(terpy)}2+.
elements.clean_text: The analogous one-dimensional zigzagged [{Cu(terpy)}/organophosphonate] pattern observed in 1 was previously seen in aliphatic organophosphonates as well. 1 was synthesized under hydrothermal reaction conditions. The adjustment of initial pH = 1 has increased the protonation level of the MTPPA ligand providing overall -2 negative charge limiting the growth in one dimension. The second two-dimensional compound [{Cu2(pbterpy)}MTPPA-H4] was synthesized using the solvothermal methods in DMF (  and Figure S2). The TOPOS analysis of 2 indicates that the one-dimensional chain figure observed in 1 has retained its character. The one-dimensional chain structures observed in [{Cu(terpy)}MTPPA-H6] (1) were connected by the second copper originating from the {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+ unit to form the two-dimensional network of 2 (). The tau-descriptor (τ5) values for Cu1 and Cu2 atoms are 0.06 and 0.02, which indicate no significant distortion of the geometry when compared to complex 1. The tetrahedral MTPPA-H4 in 2 was observed as a result of the incorporation of the second Cu(II) in {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+, which has produced the three distinct phosphonate ends. The first phosphonate end in 2 has a fully protonated R-PO3H2 unit, the second group is fully deprotonated R-PO3 -2 providing overall -2 negative charge, while the remaining two phosphonate adhesive units are half protonated R-PO3H-1 providing overall -2 negative charge. Half protonated phosphonate units of MTPPA-H4 linker follow a similar zigzagged one-dimensional chain pattern to that observed in 1. In conjunction with {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+ the fully deprotonated R-PO3 -2 unit of MTPPA-H4 is connecting the previously observed one-dimensional pattern in 1 to form the two-dimensional 2. The additional connectivity originated from the fully deprotonated phosphonate end in 2 has also produced the one-dimensional void chanel of {Cu2(MTPPA-H4)} via the {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+ end. The overall driving force behind the formation of the two-dimensional structure of 2 is the deprotonation of MTPPA-H6 ligand in 1 to accept the second Cu(II) originating from the {Cu2(pbterpy)}4+, which is analogous to {Cu(terpy)}2+.

elements.content: Coordination environment of Cu­(II) atoms in the crystal structure of complex 2. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) x, 1 + y, z; (ii) x, −1 + y, z; (iii) 2 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z; (iv) 1 – x, 1 – y, −z.
elements.clean_text: 4  Coordination environment of Cu(II) atoms in the crystal structure of complex 2. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) x, 1 + y, z; (ii) x, -1 + y, z; (iii) 2 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z; (iv) 1 - x, 1 - y, -z.

elements.content: Perspective view of 2D sheet in complex 2.
elements.clean_text: 5  Perspective view of 2D sheet in complex 2.

elements.content: As shown in , the expansion of the framework into two dimensions has produced the second distinctive void space at the center of [{Cu2(pbterpy)} (MTPPA-H4)] macrocycle with solvent-accessible voids occupying 21.0% (666.7 Å3) of the unit cell volume (3171.3 Å3) obtained using the PLATON. Analysis of solvent accessible voids in the structure was performed using the CALC SOLV within the PLATON software package with a probe radius of 1.20 Å and grin spacing of 0.2 A. Van der Waals (or ion) radii used in the analysis are C (1.70 Å), H (1.20 Å), N (1.55 Å), and P­(1.80 Å), respectively. Topological analysis has shown that complex 2 had 3,3,4L34 topology with the point symbol of {4.6.8}­{4.62.83}­{62.8}. The TOPOS analysis clearly shows how the one-dimensional zigzagged chain is connected to form the two-dimensional network (a and b). Furthermore, 2D sheet adopts −AAA– stacking to generate a 3D supramolecular framework.
elements.clean_text: As shown in , the expansion of the framework into two dimensions has produced the second distinctive void space at the center of [{Cu2(pbterpy)} (MTPPA-H4)] macrocycle with solvent-accessible voids occupying 21.0% (666.7 Å3) of the unit cell volume (3171.3 Å3) obtained using the PLATON. Analysis of solvent accessible voids in the structure was performed using the CALC SOLV within the PLATON software package with a probe radius of 1.20 Å and grin spacing of 0.2 A. Van der Waals (or ion) radii used in the analysis are C (1.70 Å), H (1.20 Å), N (1.55 Å), and P(1.80 Å), respectively. Topological analysis has shown that complex 2 had 3,3,4L34 topology with the point symbol of {4.6.8}{4.62.83}{62.8}. The TOPOS analysis clearly shows how the one-dimensional zigzagged chain is connected to form the two-dimensional network (a and b). Furthermore, 2D sheet adopts -AAA- stacking to generate a 3D supramolecular framework.

elements.content: TGA studies of [{Cu­(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)].(4.25 H2O)­(H3O) shows three successive weight losses as seen in Figure S3. The initial decrease of 7.1% is associated with loss of water molecules (4.9% calculated). The partial loss of terpyridine starts at 300 °C. Concurrent decomposition of MTPPA and terpyridine units start at 400 °C. The sharp decomposition of organic units continues until ca. 500 °C with total 56.1% weight loss of terpy + MTPPA components (58.5% calculated) and the decomposition of inorganic components continues to 800 °C. TGA of [{Cu2(pbterpy)}­MTPPA-H4] shows similar pattern as seen in Figure S4, where the decomposition of organic units start at ca. 300 °C and the slow decomposition of organic components continues until 900 °C with overall ca. 60% weight loss (65% calculated).
elements.clean_text: TGA studies of [{Cu(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)].(4.25 H2O)(H3O) shows three successive weight losses as seen in Figure S3. The initial decrease of 7.1% is associated with loss of water molecules (4.9% calculated). The partial loss of terpyridine starts at 300 °C. Concurrent decomposition of MTPPA and terpyridine units start at 400 °C. The sharp decomposition of organic units continues until ca. 500 °C with total 56.1% weight loss of terpy + MTPPA components (58.5% calculated) and the decomposition of inorganic components continues to 800 °C. TGA of [{Cu2(pbterpy)}MTPPA-H4] shows similar pattern as seen in Figure S4, where the decomposition of organic units start at ca. 300 °C and the slow decomposition of organic components continues until 900 °C with overall ca. 60% weight loss (65% calculated).

elements.content: This is the first report incorporating the tetratopic methane tetra-p-phenylphosphonic acid as a tetrahedral organophosphonate linker to produce the one-dimensional [{Cu­(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)]·(4.25H2O)­(H3O) (1) and two-dimensional [{Cu2(pbterpy)}­MTPPA-H4] (2), respectively. In addition, we provide an alternative approach for conventional SBU based MOF chemistry, by using a square pyramidal {Cu­(terpy)}2+ building unit as prefixed corner junction points providing a limited number of coordination sites on Cu­(II) from the basal plane and the apical position for the phosphonate binding to perform controlled oligomerization. This methodology has produced two compounds in one and two dimensions. The one-dimensional chain structure observed in 1 was connected into two dimensions upon the incorporation of the second copper originating from the ditopic pbterpy ligand. Blocking the copper coordination sites with tripodal organoimine ligands has increased the predictability of the ultimate structure in metal-organophosphonate chemistry while tetrahedral MTPPA ligand and long linker molecule pbterpy produced void spaces in the two-dimensional framework of 2. We are currently working on the pH optimizations to fully deprotonate the MTPPA ligand to enhance the formation of three-dimensional porous frameworks in this system.
elements.clean_text: This is the first report incorporating the tetratopic methane tetra-p-phenylphosphonic acid as a tetrahedral organophosphonate linker to produce the one-dimensional [{Cu(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)]⋅(4.25H2O)(H3O) (1) and two-dimensional [{Cu2(pbterpy)}MTPPA-H4] (2), respectively. In addition, we provide an alternative approach for conventional SBU based MOF chemistry, by using a square pyramidal {Cu(terpy)}2+ building unit as prefixed corner junction points providing a limited number of coordination sites on Cu(II) from the basal plane and the apical position for the phosphonate binding to perform controlled oligomerization. This methodology has produced two compounds in one and two dimensions. The one-dimensional chain structure observed in 1 was connected into two dimensions upon the incorporation of the second copper originating from the ditopic pbterpy ligand. Blocking the copper coordination sites with tripodal organoimine ligands has increased the predictability of the ultimate structure in metal-organophosphonate chemistry while tetrahedral MTPPA ligand and long linker molecule pbterpy produced void spaces in the two-dimensional framework of 2. We are currently working on the pH optimizations to fully deprotonate the MTPPA ligand to enhance the formation of three-dimensional porous frameworks in this system.

cln_elements.content:
As shown in , the expansion of the framework into two dimensions has produced the second distinctive void space at the center of [{Cu2(pbterpy)} (MTPPA-H4)] macrocycle with solvent-accessible voids occupying 21.0% (666.7 Å3) of the unit cell volume (3171.3 Å3) obtained using the PLATON. Analysis of solvent accessible voids in the structure was performed using the CALC SOLV within the PLATON software package with a probe radius of 1.20 Å and grin spacing of 0.2 A. Van der Waals (or ion) radii used in the analysis are C (1.70 Å), H (1.20 Å), N (1.55 Å), and P­(1.80 Å), respectively. Topological analysis has shown that complex 2 had 3,3,4L34 topology with the point symbol of {4.6.8}­{4.62.83}­{62.8}. The TOPOS analysis clearly shows how the one-dimensional zigzagged chain is connected to form the two-dimensional network (a and b). Furthermore, 2D sheet adopts −AAA– stacking to generate a 3D supramolecular framework.

TGA studies of [{Cu­(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)].(4.25 H2O)­(H3O) shows three successive weight losses as seen in Figure S3. The initial decrease of 7.1% is associated with loss of water molecules (4.9% calculated). The partial loss of terpyridine starts at 300 °C. Concurrent decomposition of MTPPA and terpyridine units start at 400 °C. The sharp decomposition of organic units continues until ca. 500 °C with total 56.1% weight loss of terpy + MTPPA components (58.5% calculated) and the decomposition of inorganic components continues to 800 °C. TGA of [{Cu2(pbterpy)}­MTPPA-H4] shows similar pattern as seen in Figure S4, where the decomposition of organic units start at ca. 300 °C and the slow decomposition of organic components continues until 900 °C with overall ca. 60% weight loss (65% calculated).

Analysis of solvent accessible voids in the structure was performed using the CALC SOLV within the PLATON software package with a probe radius of 1.20 Å and grin spacing of 0.2 A. Van der Waals (or ion) radii used in the analysis are C (1.70 Å), H (1.20 Å), N (1.55 Å), and P(1.80 Å), respectively. The TOPOS analysis clearly shows how the one-dimensional zigzagged chain is connected to form the two-dimensional network (a and b). TGA studies of [{Cu(terpy)}2(MTPPA-H5) (MTPPA-H6)].(4.25 H2O)(H3O) shows three successive weight losses as seen in Figure S3. The initial decrease of 7.1% is associated with loss of water molecules (4.9% calculated). The partial loss of terpyridine starts at 300 °C. Concurrent decomposition of MTPPA and terpyridine units start at 400 °C. The sharp decomposition of organic units continues until ca. 500 °C with total 56.1% weight loss of terpy + MTPPA components (58.5% calculated) and the decomposition of inorganic components continues to 800 °C. TGA of [{Cu2(pbterpy)}MTPPA-H4] shows similar pattern as seen in Figure S4, where the decomposition of organic units start at ca. 300 °C and the slow decomposition of organic components continues until 900 °C with overall ca. 60% weight loss (65% calculated).

decomposition temperature.condition: corresponding to the departure of guest molecules

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules
concurrent decomposition of MTPPA and terpyridine units

decomposition temperature.condition: total 56.1% weight loss of terpy + MTPPA components
